markdown:
- عندما يكون المكبسان في مستوى أفقي واحد ويتم التأثير بقوة F على المكبس الصغير كما في الشكل (1) ينتج عن هذه القوة ضغط P أسفل المكبس الصغير مباشرةً حيث :  $P = \frac{F}{a}$
- ينتقل هذا الضغط بتمامه إلى جميع أجزاء السائل وإلى السطح السفلي للمكبس الكبير فتؤثر قوة F على المكبس الكبير تعمل على <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.316,t=0.075,r=0.913,b=0.209), with ID fe1e0722-edf9-46e1-b593-0ae66f486bc0 -->

Summary : This is a labeled illustration of a hydraulic fluid system, showing two connected cylinders of different cross-sectional areas and pistons, with forces and displacements indicated, and Arabic labels.

illustration:
# System Overview :
  • Two vertical cylinders connected at the base, filled with hydraulic fluid.
  • Left cylinder is larger, labeled with cross-sectional area "A" and force "F" applied upward on a piston.
  • Right cylinder is smaller, labeled with area "a" and force "f" applied downward on a piston.
  • Both cylinders are open at the top and contain pistons.

# Labels and Notations :
  • Left piston: area "A", force "F" (upward arrow).
  • Right piston: area "a", force "f" (downward arrow).
  • Vertical distances: "y2" (left side, from fluid surface to piston), "y1" (right side, from fluid surface to piston).
  • Arabic text: "السوائل الهيدروليكي" (hydraulic fluids).
  • Figure label: "شكل 1" (Figure 1).

# Spatial Relationships :
  • The fluid level is higher in the left cylinder than in the right.
  • The two pistons are at different heights, with the left piston higher than the right.
  • The system is arranged to illustrate the principle of hydraulic force multiplication.

# Analysis :
  • The illustration demonstrates Pascal's principle, showing how a small force "f" applied to a small area "a" can generate a larger force "F" on a larger area "A" via hydraulic fluid.
  • The difference in heights (y2 and y1) and areas (A and a) visually represent the mechanical advantage in hydraulic systems. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.065,t=0.072,r=0.308,b=0.231), with ID a4a97a89-2b17-4a88-bb2a-258233c7f3eb -->

$P = \frac{F}{A} : \text{تحريكه لأعلى حيث}$ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.593,t=0.211,r=0.824,b=0.241), with ID 98689be1-ab8e-4a29-bb54-911f31eaae67 -->

- إذا تسببت القوة F في تحريك المكبس الصغير مسافة y₁ لأسفل فإن المكبس الكبير يتأثر بقوة F وتسبب تحركه مسافة y₂ لأعلى، ويطبق قانون بقاء الطاقة (في حالة المكبس الهيدروليكي المثالي) فإن: <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.066,t=0.244,r=0.833,b=0.297), with ID 631a40be-2fc7-45b5-9374-3cdf81f43060 -->

$الشغل المبذول على المكبس الصغير = الشغل الناتج عند المكبس الكبير.$ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.289,t=0.299,r=0.822,b=0.322), with ID 4953c4ff-d573-4f65-b7fd-2ac66feeeb50 -->

$ \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{f}} = \frac{y_1}{y_2} $ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.618,t=0.326,r=0.760,b=0.380), with ID 56016a40-dc92-43c4-9b60-b2a028cf2a64 -->

Summary : This image shows a mathematical equation relating two products, "fy₁" and "Fy₂", set equal to each other.

equation:
Equation Content : 
  • The equation displayed is: fy₁ = Fy₂.
  • Subscripts: y₁ and y₂ are used, indicating possibly different variables or indices.
  • The letters "f" and "F" are distinct, with "f" lowercase and "F" uppercase.

Formatting : 
  • The equation is centered within a rectangular box with a wavy blue border.
  • All characters are in a serif font, typical of mathematical typesetting.

Analysis : 
  • The equation asserts equality between two expressions, possibly indicating a relationship or conservation law between the terms "fy₁" and "Fy₂".
  • The use of subscripts and case distinction suggests the variables may represent different quantities or parameters. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.310,t=0.325,r=0.453,b=0.380), with ID cc2a5171-39d0-4603-9cfd-caf43618c787 -->

- أي أن المكبس الكبير يتحرك مسافة صغيرة إلى أعلى بتأثير إزاحة كبيرة للمكبس الصغير إلى أسفل، <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.063,t=0.380,r=0.836,b=0.408), with ID 7ed3dfe0-9e54-45cb-8b59-f98ea8a0634b -->

ويمكن الوصول لنفس الاستنتاج كالتالى : <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.499,t=0.409,r=0.823,b=0.434), with ID 22512f67-aa18-42c7-8d5b-5b4648b95a13 -->

عند إزاحة المكبس الصغير إلى أسفل وحيث إن السائل غير قابل للانضغاط فإن حجم السائل المزاح من  
أنبوبة المكبس الصغير = حجم السائل المزاح إلى أنبوبة المكبس الكبير. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.064,t=0.436,r=0.824,b=0.484), with ID 8bdb1358-8c55-46ae-a282-1311c1790c16 -->

Summary : This image presents a mathematical equation expressing the proportional relationship between two ratios.

equation:
Equation Details :
  • The equation shown is: A/a = y₁/y₂.
  • The variables are uppercase A, lowercase a, y₁ (y subscript 1), and y₂ (y subscript 2).
  • The equation is enclosed in a blue wavy-bordered box.

Analysis :
  • The equation states that the ratio of A to a is equal to the ratio of y₁ to y₂, indicating a direct proportionality between these pairs of variables. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.605,t=0.488,r=0.761,b=0.542), with ID a80765ad-6222-4d3f-b86a-ca903f608bb0 -->

$ \therefore \quad A\,y_2 = a\,y_1 $ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.316,t=0.488,r=0.478,b=0.542), with ID d52acce5-908b-46ee-8776-33140d481441 -->

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Scene Overview :
  • The image shows two vertical cylinders of different diameters connected at the base by a U-shaped tube filled with liquid.
  • The left cylinder is larger, labeled "A" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "F" applied.
  • The right cylinder is smaller, labeled "a" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "f" applied.
  • The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating equilibrium.

Technical Details :
  • The pistons are circular and fit tightly in their respective cylinders.
  • The forces "F" and "f" are shown as arrows pointing downward on the pistons.
  • The areas of the pistons are labeled "A" (large) and "a" (small).
  • The liquid is colored blue for clarity.
  • The diagram is labeled "شكل ۲" (Figure 2) in Persian.

Spatial Relationships :
  • The larger cylinder is on the left, the smaller on the right.
  • The pistons are at the same vertical height, indicating equal pressure transmission.
  • The U-shaped tube connects the two cylinders at the base, allowing fluid communication.

Analysis :
  • The figure visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  • The system demonstrates how a small force applied to a small piston can balance a larger force on a larger piston if the ratio of forces equals the ratio of areas (F/A = f/a).
  • The equal liquid levels confirm equilibrium and pressure balance in the system. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.476,r=0.268,b=0.614), with ID 46ede8b4-7103-4a9f-aa54-0d621bf49a0f -->

- لكي يعود الكبسان في مستوى أفقي واحد كما في الشكل (2) يجب التأثير على الكبـس الكبير بقوة F لأسفل. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.313,t=0.549,r=0.837,b=0.597), with ID 9bbf7d51-d922-4cea-ba05-4465ec35b54c -->

Summary : This diagram illustrates the equilibrium state of a hydraulic piston system when both pistons are at the same horizontal level, showing the relationship between applied forces and areas, and the resulting pressure equality.

illustration:
Title & Context :
  • Title at top: "حالات المكبس الهيدروليكى عند الاستقرار" ("States of the hydraulic piston at equilibrium").
  • Subheading: "المكبان في نفس المستوى الأفقي" ("The two pistons at the same horizontal level").
  • The diagram is part of a larger set, but this crop focuses on the case where both pistons are level.

Diagram Details :
  • U-shaped vessel filled with liquid, with two pistons labeled "1" (left, small area a) and "2" (right, large area A).
  • Force "f" applied downward on piston 1; force "F" applied downward on piston 2.
  • Both pistons are shown at the same height above the liquid.
  • Labels: "a" (area of piston 1), "A" (area of piston 2), "f" (force on piston 1), "F" (force on piston 2).

Equations & Annotations :
  • Pressure equality: "P₁ = P₂".
  • Force-area relationship: "f / a = F / A".
  • These equations are written below the diagram, indicating the principle of hydraulic equilibrium.

Spatial Relationships :
  • Both pistons are aligned horizontally.
  • The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating no net movement.

Analysis :
  • The diagram visually demonstrates Pascal's principle: when pistons are at the same level in a hydraulic system, the pressure transmitted is equal on both sides, leading to the proportional relationship between force and area.
  • The system is in equilibrium, with no net flow or movement, as indicated by equal heights and pressures. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.509,t=0.627,r=0.886,b=0.904), with ID b3283c73-7de2-4077-a341-cce4c56f9706 -->

Summary : This diagram illustrates the principle of communicating vessels with pistons at different heights, showing how pressure is transmitted in fluids and how it is affected by height differences and applied forces.

illustration:
# Title & Labels :
  • Title at top: "المكبسـان في مستويين مختلفين" (The pistons at different levels).
  • Two main panels: left and right, each showing a U-shaped vessel with pistons at different heights.
  • Labels: "a" and "A" for piston areas, "f" and "F" for applied forces, "h" for height difference, "ρ" for fluid density, "g" for gravity, "P1" and "P2" for pressures at points 1 and 2.

# Left Panel :
  • Shows a U-tube with a small piston (area "a", force "f") on the left at a lower level, and a large piston (area "A", force "F") on the right at a higher level.
  • Height difference "h" is marked between the two pistons.
  • Arrows indicate direction of applied forces and pressure transmission.
  • Equation: P1 = P2, and f/a = F/A + ρgh.

# Right Panel :
  • Shows a U-tube with the small piston (area "a", force "f") on the left at a higher level, and the large piston (area "A", force "F") on the right at a lower level.
  • Height difference "h" is marked, but now the right side is lower.
  • Arrows indicate direction of applied forces and pressure transmission.
  • Equation: P1 = P2, and f/a + ρgh = F/A.

# Equations :
  • Both panels use the principle P1 = P2 (pressure at the same horizontal level in a connected fluid is equal).
  • Left: f/a = F/A + ρgh.
  • Right: f/a + ρgh = F/A.

# Visual Elements :
  • Simple line drawings, black and blue color scheme.
  • Pistons and forces are clearly labeled.
  • Dashed lines indicate fluid levels and height differences.

# Analysis :
  • The diagram demonstrates how pressure is transmitted in a fluid with pistons at different heights, incorporating the effect of hydrostatic pressure (ρgh).
  • The equations show that the force required on one piston depends on both the force on the other piston and the height difference, due to the added (or subtracted) hydrostatic pressure.
  • The left and right panels illustrate the two possible configurations: when the larger piston is higher or lower than the smaller piston, affecting the pressure balance accordingly. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.119,t=0.667,r=0.598,b=0.902), with ID f624bd65-c253-4f97-8864-cb78bd39e21a -->

حيث : (ρ) كثافة السائل ، (h) ارتفاع عمود السائل بين المكبسين. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.393,t=0.912,r=0.887,b=0.935), with ID b9e4d337-4f1c-498a-a37d-899c71ff7554 -->

$1 \cdot \xi$ <!-- marginalia, from page 0 (l=0.872,t=0.947,r=0.907,b=0.964), with ID 233bf728-cc39-4941-91c8-3571744f204d -->
